item.title: 22 Pieces of Career Advice They Don't Teach You in School | Sahil Bloom
item.description:
Here are the 22 pieces of career advice from Sahil Bloom’s “22 Pieces of Career Advice They Don’t Teach You in School” — the distilled lessons he wished he’d known early in his career:

  1. Be valuable. Create value first; money follows value.

  2. Durable things take a long time to build. No shortcuts.

  3. Be the person who can figure it out. Solve problems even when you don’t initially know how.

  4. There are no style points in life. Simple execution matters more than flashy moves.

  5. People want to do business with people they like. Be likable and pleasant to work with.

  6. The best opportunities look like tiny cracks, not open doors. Big wins often come from small openings.

  7. Inputs are great, but you’re paid for your outputs. Focus on results.

  8. Extraordinary outputs require extraordinary inputs. Be willing to put in hard work.

  9. The ability to take feedback is a long-term competitive advantage. Seek and embrace critique.

  10. Seek out rooms where you don’t feel like you belong. Growth happens outside your comfort zone.

  11. Always focus on doing. Execution beats talk every time.

  12. Potential is nothing without execution. Deliver on what you promise.

  13. Everything matters. Consistency counts in small and big things alike.

  14. Learn to sell. Communication and persuasion are core career skills.

  15. Build a reputation for reliability. Consistent follow-through is rare and valuable.

  16. If you want to accomplish anything significant, you have to work hard. Hard work sets the foundation.

  17. Don’t follow your passion; follow your energy. Energy fuels deep engagement and learning.

  18. Be selective in the games you choose to play. Win where your strengths give you advantage.

  19. Closed mouths don’t get fed. Ask for what you want when you’ve earned it.

  20. Do the “old fashioned” things well. Basic professionalism and manners still matter.

  21. Side hustles are usually just distractions. Many “extra” income streams steal focus from what matters most.

  22. Your employer (probably) doesn’t care about you. Companies prioritize business outcomes over personal loyalty — act accordingly.

Sahil’s advice focuses less on technical skills and more on mindset, execution, value creation, relationships, and real-world work habits. These are things you don’t learn in school but that determine long-term career progress.

https://www.sahilbloom.com/newsletter/22-pieces-of-career-advice-they-dont-teach-you-in-school

item.title: The Real AI Risk Nobody Told You About | Sahil Bloom
item.description:
The Real AI Risk Nobody Told You About

4 principles (and clear rules) to protect myself from AI Brain:

Principle 1: Embrace First-Pass Thinking

  • I think before I prompt.
  • I write before I refine.
  • I decide before I optimize.

Principle 2: Preserve Cognitive Friction

  • I allow boredom to exist.
  • I seek out solitude.
  • I sit with problems longer than feels efficient.
  • I slow down my thinking

Principle 3: Do Less, But Deeper

  • I identify the 2-3 most important things.
  • I say no to most ideas.
  • I measure quality, not quantity.

Principle 4: Do More Human Things

  • I prioritize in-person interaction.
  • I do physically hard things.

item.title: 35 Life Lessons From 35 Years | Sahil Bloom
item.description:
Here’s the full list of 35 Life Lessons from 35 Years from Sahil Bloom’s newsletter — straight, clear, and in order:

  1. You can reinvent yourself whenever you want.

  2. Tolerance for uncertainty is the most valuable human trait.

  3. Energy is the most attractive human trait.

  4. Nobody cares.

  5. Always get your dopamine from action.

  6. Your professional success is proportional to your ability to figure it out.

  7. Never let your head outsmart your gut.

  8. Showing up is the key to life.

  9. Fear comes from inexperience, not incapability.

  10. Learn to work without validation.

  11. Anything above zero compounds.

  12. Take pride in finishing things.

  13. Life improves when you embrace your inner extremes.

  14. The most important things take a long time to build.

  15. Be unapologetically yourself.

  16. Do what most people avoid.

  17. Life will test you with the same challenge until you learn the lesson.

  18. Your standards decide your future.

  19. Choose a partner you actually like being around.

  20. If you want people to believe in you, start carrying yourself like someone worth believing in.

  21. Don’t wait.

  22. Confidence isn’t about knowing you’ll win.

  23. Stress and anxiety feed on idleness.

  24. Working out will rewire your brain.

  25. Energy fuels growth.

  26. Nobody is thinking about you.

  27. You have to know when to stop.

  28. Do hard things every single day.

  29. Reliability is more important than talent.

  30. Don’t complain about anything.

  31. Emotional control is the ultimate sign of personal growth.

  32. You can just do things.

  33. You’re going to miss this.

  34. Nobody is coming to save you.

  35. You’re one year of focus away from people calling you lucky.

item.title: 26 Money Rules For 2026 | Sahil Bloom
item.description:
26 Money Rules For 2026

Here are the 26 Money Rules for 2026 as shared by Sahil Bloom — practical financial principles and mindsets to guide how you think about and use money in your life.

  1. No unforced errors. Avoid avoidable mistakes like impulse buys, unnecessary debt, and emotional investing.
  2. Never allow self-worth to be dictated by net worth. Your value isn’t tied to money.
  3. Track financial progress like an athlete tracks performance. You can’t improve what you don’t measure.
  4. Increase your Margin of Freedom. Keep lifestyle below means and create slack in your finances.
  5. Focus on value, impact, and service over money. Money follows value creation.
  6. Treat income as the leverage point, not investments. Growing earning power often beats optimizing returns.
  7. Spend more for quality, not for brand. Quality often costs less in the long run.
  8. Always fade trends and external expectations. Don’t buy into cultural financial timelines.
  9. Debt is a tool, not the enemy, but use it sparingly. Avoid debt for depreciating purchases.
  10. Follow a 24-hour rule for non-essential purchases above a threshold. Delay impulse buying.
  11. Remember that investments require time, not just money. Consider both money and time inputs.
  12. Remember that returns come in many forms beyond money. Access, learning, and network can matter just as much.
  13. Never think twice about investments in yourself. Fitness, learning, and health pay huge dividends.
  14. Never use money to optimize the life out of your life. Don’t remove meaningful friction that gives life texture.
  15. Create a monthly financial check-in with your partner. Alignment prevents money-related conflict.
  16. Focus on expanding your savings rate. The gap between income and expenses is the real asset.
  17. Work towards a 12-month emergency fund. Peace of mind and optionality in hard times are worth it.
  18. Run quarterly disaster simulations. Plan for worst-case financial scenarios.
  19. Don’t waste energy on small games (unless it brings joy). Focus on major financial decisions, not trivia.
  20. Use the Bought Status Test. Ask if you’d buy something if no one knew—cuts through social signaling.
  21. Consider a barbell approach to investments. Balance safe, steady holdings with small high-risk bets.
  22. Ruthlessly eliminate complexity. Simplicity prevents mistakes and improves control.
  23. Automate payment of small recurring expenses. Free up mental energy for strategic money decisions.
  24. Conduct quarterly audits of recurring expenses. Find and cut hidden costs like unused subscriptions.
  25. Tip generously whenever you’re able. Generosity compounds happiness and goodwill.
  26. Use money as a tool for more meaningful forms of wealth. Use money to buy time, health, experiences, and purpose, not just stuff.

item.title: The Costs of Entry in Life | Sahil Bloom
item.description:
The Costs of Entry in Life

Every single thing you want in life comes at a cost.

There is always a cost of entry. An unavoidable price you must pay to achieve the things you say you want.

Some are obvious…

  • Hard work is a cost of entry for business success.
  • Discipline is a cost of entry for physical health.
  • Practice is a cost of entry for skill mastery.

…but some are not.

A lot of problems in life arise when you’re simply unaware that the struggle you’re facing is actually the cost of entry. You waste energy complaining about it—or worse, trying to avoid it—but in doing so, you hold yourself back from what you’re truly capable of.

In this piece, I shared seven non-obvious costs of entry you have to pay to live the life you want…

https://www.sahilbloom.com/newsletter/the-costs-of-entry-in-life

item.title: The Hercules Principle | Sahil Bloom
item.description:
The Hercules Principle

No one is coming to save you. No one will fix your problems. No one will change your mindsets. No one will hand you the things you want in life.

It’s just you. It’s all on you.

Contrary to what your first reaction to this may be, it’s not morbid or depressing. It’s empowering. Even inspiring.

The Hercules Principle is a reminder that you are in control. Don’t look out. Look in. You have within you everything you need…

item.title: The Antelope Principle: How to Chase the Right Things | Sahil Bloom
item.description:
Monday: The Antelope Principle: How to Chase the Right Things

A lion can easily catch a field mouse—but the energy it burns in the process exceeds the calories it gains. A lion that spends its days chasing mice will eventually starve. To thrive, it must hunt antelope.

Every single day, you face the same choice:

  • Chase field mice: the small, urgent problems and opportunities that pull at your attention; or
  • Hunt antelope: the big, important pursuits that require focus and effort but actually move the needle.

Busyness can trick you into feeling productive, but motion isn’t momentum. A rocking horse moves all day and never goes anywhere.

The lion that chases mice will starve. The lion that hunts antelope will thrive.

What are you hunting today?

https://www.sahilbloom.com/newsletter/the-antelope-principle-how-to-chase-the-right-things

item.title: 24 Ways to Change Your Life in 2024 | Sahil Bloom
item.description:
24 Ways to Change Your Life in 2024 by Sahil Bloom

Life Actions

  • To identify what to prioritize in your days, use my Energy Calendar Technique.
  • To improve your focus, turn on Grayscale Mode.
  • To improve the quality of your outcomes, spend more time around the big thinkers in your circle.
  • To unlock new asymmetric upside in your life, schedule a Think Day.
  • To make dramatic progress in 30 days, try my 30-for-30 approach.

Work Actions

  • To improve your focus and get more done, get a focus app and set your phone on Do Not Disturb mode.
  • To reduce the impact of attention residue, take short breaks between meetings.
  • To improve your balance of professional time, assess your current mix and make small changes to it.
  • To prioritize more effectively, use an Eisenhower Matrix.
  • To improve your work efficiency, batch email and message processing into 1-3 condensed windows.

Health Actions

  • To improve your mental and physical health, go for more walks.
  • To improve your health and grit, get cold more often.
  • To fall asleep faster, try the 4-7-8 method.
  • To eat healthier, do all your shopping on the outer perimeter of the store.
  • To start your day with energy, try my 5-5-5-30 method.
    When you wake up, do 5 push-ups, 5 squats, 5 lunges, and a 30-second plank. You can do it while you are brewing coffee or right when you get out of bed. It will jumpstart your metabolism and give you a boost of energy to start the day.

Money Actions

  • To set your wealth on autopilot, create an automated direct deposit into an investment account every month.
  • To improve the quality of your spending, never think twice about investments in yourself, but wait 48 hours on material purchases.
    Investments in yourself include books, sleep, fitness, network, quality food, mental health, and personal development. Never think twice on these.
  • To clear your mind, automate all basic financial tasks such as paying bills, credit cards, and investing.

References

24 Ways to Change Your Life in 2024

item.title: The Letter to Your Future Self | Sahil Bloom
item.description:
The Letter to Your Future Self by Sahil Bloom

Summary by Sahil
  • On January 1, 2014, I wrote a letter to my future self just before graduating. Ten years later, I opened it, and it hit me hard. Everyone should do this.
  • My core reflection: We have the answers, we just haven’t asked the right questions yet.
  • To write your own letter to your future self, cover four key areas:
    1. Reflections on the present,
    2. Vision for the future,
    3. Changes to make, and
    4. Fun predictions.

Use a technology tool (like FutureMe) or store a physical letter somewhere safe. Set a calendar reminder to open it on the set date in the future.

References

The Letter to Your Future Self

item.title: The Think Day: Your Secret Weapon | Sahil Bloom
item.description:
The Think Day: Your Secret Weapon by Sahil Bloom

Summary by Sahil
  • In the 1980s, Microsoft founder Bill Gates began an annual tradition he called the Think Week. Gates would seclude himself in a remote location, shut off all of his communication, and spend an entire week dedicated to reading, learning, and thinking.
  • While I knew I didn’t have an entire week to dedicate to it (due to early career demands, family priorities, etc.), I figured I could adapt something with a similar core ethos and vision. The Think Day was my creation and I want to share its value with all of you today…
  • Pick one day each month (or quarter) to step back from all of your day-to-day professional demands. Seclude yourself (mentally or physically), shut off all of your notifications on your devices, and put up an out-of-office response. The goal is to spend the entire day reading, learning, journaling, and THINKING.

References

The Think Day: Your Secret Weapon

item.title: Toolkit - Mental Time Travel: A Cheat Code for Success | Sahil Bloom
item.description:
Toolkit - Mental Time Travel: A Cheat Code for Success by Sahil Bloom

Summary by Sahil
  • I have spent time with a lot of very successful people. I have observed two common trends:
    1. A struggle to appreciate the present and
    2. A struggle to identify the key actions to create the desired future.
  • The tool we can all use to fight back: Mental Time Travel. This involves the vivid imagination of both the past and the future. You use your mind to figuratively “travel” to the experienced past and the envisioned future.
  • Professionally, Mental Time Travel allows us to consider both
    1. the gap between where we are and where we want to be and
    2. the gain between where we were and where we are.

Personally, Mental Time Travel allows us to build a robust gratitude practice and appreciate the present state.

References

Toolkit - Mental Time Travel: A Cheat Code for Success

item.title: Toolkit - The Magic of Character Invention | Sahil Bloom
item.description:
Toolkit - The Magic of Character Invention by Sahil Bloom

Summary by Sahil
  • We all struggle with some degree of self-doubt and fear of failure. It’s particularly common among ambitious high-achievers, who, by definition, are constantly putting themselves in situations that are on the edge of their current competency level.
  • Character Invention: Create a character in your mind who can show up in the way you want to and teach yourself to “flip the switch” to become this character when necessary.
  • Character Invention in three steps:
    1. Identify the situations where you’d like to show up as the best version of yourself,
    2. Envision the character you would like to embody in each situation, and
    3. Get yourself some reps by turning on this character in those situations.

References

Toolkit - The Magic of Character Invention

item.title: Toolkit - The Public Speaking Guide | Sahil Bloom
item.description:
The Public Speaking Guide by Sahil Bloom

Summary

Confession: I am a nervous public speaker. But confident public speaking is a critical skill, so we need a set of strategies to increase our confidence and perform as the best version of ourselves.

  • Prep Strategies:
  1. Study the best speakers and learn from them,
  2. Create a clear storytelling structure, and
  3. Build “lego blocks” but avoid rote memorization.
  • Pre-Stage Strategies:
  1. Address the Spotlight Effect and ask “so what?” about your worst fears,
  2. Get into character and turn on the best version of yourself, and
  3. Eliminate stress with a simple breathing technique.
  • Delivery Strategies:
  1. Cut the tension in the crowd at the outset,
  2. Use big, broad gestures and avoid touching your pockets or torso, and
  3. Move with purposeful, slow steps.

References

Toolkit - The Public Speaking Guide
